Posts.Content: Goals1 .. a lot of us have irregular calcium deposits in our breasts .. some undergo a biopsy, some do not.   Is your doctor a breast specialist, or a general practioner?  Most of the time the calcium deposit is just that .. and in dense breasts they show up more as we age.  I know that is not much help, but I have had over 15 biopsies on irregular or suspicious spots .... follow your gut.  take care, Jene
Posts.Title: findings

Posts.Content: Yes, there a lot of us that go through the same thing you are experiencing .. fear not .. the crying will get less, and your mojo will return.  So thankful that you have been diagnosed .. now start the good thoughts.  I just had a bilateral March 1st.  I read every day trying to figure out if what my Docs want me to do is what I really want to do.  I am a little older than most on here, but if I can live 10 more years cancer free, I will be one very happy old gal.  Keep good thoughts, and channel good mojo .. ask questions, read, read, read .. find out the type of cell you have and investigate everything.  This is a good learning time not only for you, but for all those around you ... and ... do not be afraid to say the dreaded word "cancer"  .. it is now a part of our lives and yes, we can live with it!
Posts.Title: Hi everyone

Posts.Content: Smart choice given your family history.  I am 71, have had over a dozen biopsies over the past 40 years, had a lumpectomy 12 years ago with LCIS and just this past December my mammo showed BC .. after a lot of research I chose a great team of BC doctors .. have since had a double mx .. bc not outside the breast .. no lymph involvement .. but I chose to have the  BRCA 1 & 2 because my oldest sister passed at 47 with bc .. 2nd sister developed bc at 81 (did not pass due to bc) .. but I have one daughter and 6 granddaughters .. they were my reason.  OK .. I tested negative.  However I have a great niece (granddaughter to the my sister that passed at 47) who at 45 developed bc .. had a double mx, and tested posititve on the genetic test ... so how do we know what to do in the "family circle"?  I say if there is any sign of bc at any age, do a double, and be sure you are under the very best bc team of doctors you can find!  Wishing you the best,
Posts.Title: genetic testing

Posts.Content: So glad I found this site where women can talk to women.  My journey started over 30 years ago with a biopsy .. which I have had to date around a dozen .. most were clear, but ten years ago I was told that I was LCIS (Lobular Carcinoma in Situ).  The lower outside quarter of my right breast was removed, and I was pronounced with clear borders.  Having a routine annual mammogram, this year a small 1cm lump was noticed, and after further mammo's, an MRI & biopsy I was told I had invasive lobular and invasive ductal both in early stage in the right breast.  I sat about to find an all female group of doctors .. so glad I did the work.  My primary surgeon is the head of the breast center, plastic surgeon, and oncologist are also women.  Had a bi-lateral mastectomy March 1st and I must say that I am one blessed woman .. early stage .. found ductal in situ in the left breast, also early stage (so happy I did both).  The cancer had not gone in to the lymph glands .. now comes the decision to take or not to take Anastrozole.  I am 71 years old .. in excellent health .. very active .. what do I do?  After reading up on this medication, I am not sure I want to subject myself to the side effects, and possibly end up with problems.  I am thinking 71, and if I can have a good 10 more years .. in good health .. I do not want to take Anastrozole.  And do we really know if the medication gives us an advantage ....... any in put would be greatly appreciated.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole - to take or not?

Posts.Content: Ellen .. what type & stage was your breast cancer?  Mine was early stage, 1cm, lymph nodes clear.  I am wondering with all the side effects that I have read about if it is worth it for me to take Anastrozole . I am 71, in good health except my cholesterol is on the high side (& I understand that Anastrozole can push it higher).  I am still reading & blogging in hopes that I can make a decision within the next couple of weeks and tell my Oncologist.  Thanks for your reply.  Jene
Posts.Title: Anastrozole - to take or not?

Posts.Content: Thank you Christine, the more information I can gather the better for my decision .. what type cancer did you have?  Jene
Posts.Title: Anastrozole - to take or not?

Posts.Content: Misty .. same here with the rib pain .. I am wondering if it  is the expander (only on my left side).  The ribs have bothered me since my surgery 3/1, but I thought it would settle down as the expander got more moist or settled in.  The right one is good, don't even know it is there, except as you say .. feels like my bra is to tight, and I do not wear one 98% of the time.  Today is ";pump up" day, so I will talk to the Doc and hopefully she will have an answer.  take care, Jene
Posts.Title: pain in ribs and trying not to go mad

Posts.Content: My pain is with the stitches that hold the expanders .. when the expanders come out my pain should stop  and the Doc says there should not be any pain with the implants .  I am still being "expanded", and will be for a couple more weeks, then wait two months for the muscle & skin to get adjusted, then surgery in August for implants.  Will be so happy when this part with the expanders is over. take care, Jene
Posts.Title: pain in ribs and trying not to go mad

Posts.Content: Misty .. sorry it has taken me a few days to respond .. my plastic surgeon says the expanders are stitched to cartledge right at our ribs (there is some long name for it, but I forgot to write it down) and almost everyone has some degree of pain .. she assures me the pain will go away after the expanders are out.  We have been working out in the yard quite a bit and my left side seems to be easing up a little .. my doc said I was lucky that I do not have any discomfort in the right rib area.  take care, Jene
Posts.Title: pain in ribs and trying not to go mad

Posts.Content: Jazzmyne .. sorry to hear about your cancer.  I had two sisters that had breast cancer, one left us at a young age the other lived to be 87, and here I am at 71 .. had a double mastectomy March 1 and very happy with my decision.  The cancer was in the right breast, however when they took the left, it also had cancer which did not show on the mammogram or MRI.  I have an excellent team of doctors,  My plastic surgeon has done a beautiful job.  Surgery one day and out the next (with tubes for 11 days, easy to take care of, however did have home health nurses come by to check on me).  My scars are healing beautifully, and I have no pain (except for the expanders, which are finally settling down).  Take care,
Posts.Title: Too many wild thoughts!
